Authors: Zu-Yu Yang, Jin-Hua Ran, Xiao-Quan Wang
Title:
Three Genome-based Phylogeny of Cupressaceae s.l.: Nuclear
Gene Evolution in the Rare Polyploids of Conifers and Further Evidence
for the Southern Hemisphere Biogeography
Keywords:
Cupressaceae s.l.; LEAFY (LFY); NEEDLY (NLY); Chloroplast
matK; Mitochondrial rps3; Gymnosperm phylogeny; Polyploid; Gondwana
Abstract:
While DNA sequences from different genomes have been
widely utilized in phylogenetic reconstruction at various taxonomic
levels, it is still difficult to use nuclear genes to reconstruct
phylogenies of plant groups with a large genome and complex gene
families, such as gymnosperms. Here, we use two single-copy nuclear
genes LEAFY and NEEDLY that originated from an ancient gene duplication,
together with chloroplast matK and mitochondrial rps3 genes, to
reconstruct the phylogeny of the important conifer family Cupressaceae
s.l., based on a complete sampling of its 32 genera covering all
continents except Antarctica. It is very exciting that the gene trees
generated from the three genome data are highly congruent in topology,
supporting the basal position of Cunninghamia and the seven-subfamily
classification. In particular, the estimated divergence times based on
different data sets not only correspond well with each other but also
with the oldest fossil records. These results may imply that we have
obtained the organismal phylogeny of Cupressaceae s.l.. In addition,
possible origins of all three polyploid genera or species of conifers
(Fitzroya, Sequioa and Juniperus chinensis) were investigated based on
phylogenetic reconstruction and the evolutionary patterns of LEAFY and
NEEDLY genes, and a hybrid origin was suggested for Cupressus, Fitzroya
and Sequioa. Moreover, we found that the biogeographic history of
Cupressaceae s.l. is closely associated with the separation between
Laurasia and Gondwanawa and the further break-up of the later, although
long distance dispersal could have occurred. Our study also provides new
evidence for the phylogeny of gymnosperms.
